Adjudication: The functional perspective
Adjudication is the process of determining if a claim will be paid, and if so, how much you going to pay. It includes everything from when the claim is first reported, to issuing the final payment and closing the claim. In ClaimCenter, this includes completing all of the relevant activities on the claim and its exposures. Moving the claim exposures to ability to pay, means updating the data on those objects so that all of the data requirements are met to make them payable

Common questions during adjudication
There may be two issues involved in evaluating an insurer's responsibility regarding a loss. First, was there a policy in effect at the time of the loss?  And, do any of the coverages on the policy cover the loss? Not only must a policy be in effect the time of the loss, but there must be coverage for the specific loss. Coverage Terms, such deductibles and limits will determine if a payment should be made and how high it should be.

To help determine the insurer’s responsibility, the claim must include the where, when and how the loss occurred. It's also important to know if other partie  were involved. This may have a bearing on payment to third parties, or to determine shared responsibility for the claim.  Sometimes, there is relevant information available from agencies. The Metropolitan Reporting Bureau provides nationwide police accident and incident reports in the Unite States. ClaimCenter has built-in support for this service. For Workers' Comp claims, other relevant information may include  medical bills and reports.

Adjudication includes determining how much to pay the claimant Sometimes this is a simple process, but it may include determining whether certain procedures are covered and whether they are medically necessary, or whether the worker could accept modified duty.

Determine Compensability on workers' compensation claims
The purpose of this step in WC claim processing is to decide on whether or not the claim is compensable (payable). This is usually one of the first tasks that adjusters take on when working on a WC claim, due to its time-sensitive nature. Determining compensability is also referred to as "claim acceptance“

 The Compensability Decision is one of the most important (and cost-saving) components of WC claim processing. Many state laws and other regulations dictate that if a carrier does not respond or accept a claim within a particular time window, the claim is automatically compensable. Furthermore, cases of fraud andfor injuries sustained outside of employment could be pinpointed and the claim denied as a result- Each jurisdiction may have different amounts of time for determining compensability. This is known as the "Denial Period". For example, the state of Illinois (IL) mandates that the carrier must make a compensability decision within three days of the loss date. The state of  Connecticut (CT) gives twenty-eight calendar days for the decision. Jurisdictional details such as the logic determining when claim acceptance is due (the compensability due date), which jurisdictions are configured, and document templates to communicate letters of claim acceptance or denying a claim are available for users with the appropriate permissions (and access to the Administration screen). Administration of this "Denial Period" for jurisdictions is covered in the "Workers’ Comp: Administering ClaimCenter" lesson. Depending on your configuration, the 'Determine Compensability" activity may or may not be created on imported claims, or on sample data claims.

Exposures
On Workers' Compensation claims, exposures are created automatically based on the losses (medical, indemnity, and liability) incurred. Each exposure tracks a potential payout from a single coverage to a single claimant. Exposures can be created automatically by Gosu rules. This is often done for workers' comp claims, and it usually occurs along with claim setup. Exposures can also be created manually by adjusters.

In the example above, two exposures are required: one for statutory workers' compensation and one for employer's liability.

slides.originalNotes:
Incidents
An incident is a single instance of loss. It is the property or person that is damaged or injured. In the example above, the claim is a workers' compensation claim in which a worker was injured, and employer liability is involved.

Typically, information about the incidents is gathered during the intake process. This information is useful in determining the indemnities that will need to be paid from the claim. Incidents serve two primary purposes:

They allow users to capture information about the loss without having to create exposures. This is helpful when the user creating the claim does not have sufficient expertise to create exposures (such as a customer service rep) or when the user is unsure of what exposures will be needed at the time the claim is created (such as when it is not immediately obvious which coverage covers the loss).

They allow shared information when an injury is used across multiple exposures.

Reserve lines
A reserve line can be thought as an account set aside for one specific aspect of exposure processing. It contains both credits and debits, and its size is equal to the sum of the credits minus the sum of the debits. The credits are added to account for money that will potentially be paid against an exposure, and the debits are usually payments against the exposure.

An exposure must have a reserve line in order for it to be payable. Without a reserve line, there is no money set aside to pay the exposure. ClaimCenter uses the term "reserve line" to refer to the total amount of money set aside for exposure payment, and •reserve transaction" refers to the transaction that increases or decreases in the amount of money set aside for exposure payment.

slides.originalNotes:
Cost types
The adjudication of an exposure can result in two broad payments types: indemnity and expense. An indemnity payment is a payment made to a claimant to make them whole agaim For example, if the exposure is for collision coverage to the insured, then the indemnity payment is intended to repair or replace the damaged vehicle.

An expense payment is a payment made to cover costs incurred by the insurer while processing the exposure. For example, if the exposure is for collision coverage to the insured,  an independent auto inspector may have been hired to survey and assess the auto damage. The expense payment goes to the inspector for services rendered. This is a cost that the insurer incurred as a result of processing the claim and is not passed on to the claimant.

A claims processing system can have more than two cost types. Typically, each cost type ultimately belongs to eitherindemnity or expense. The ClaimCenter base application has four cost types: Claim Cost(indemnity), Adjusting and other expense(expense),  Defense and cost containment (expense), and Unspecified.
